channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Musharraf 'barred from parliament bid'
item.description: Election officials in Pakistan barred former President Pervez Musharraf from running for a parliament seat, his lawyer said Tuesday.

item.title: Gold plunges to 2-year low
item.description: Gold prices have suffered their sharpest fall since the 1980s, heightening fears among investors that the precious metal's decade-long bull run has ended.

item.title: Bird flu: Fears over 4-year-old 'carrier'
item.description: Doctors say the discovery of a 4-year-old carrier of the H7N9 virus who shows no symptoms of the potentially lethal virus is a worrying development that could make the spread of the infection more difficult to monitor.

item.title: Thatcher's coffin taken to Westminster
item.description: The body of Britain's first woman prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, will be taken to a chapel at Westminster on Tuesday to lie overnight before a ceremonial funeral in London on Wednesday.

item.title: 'Hurt and anger' part of Thatcher legacy
item.description: Britain has still not come to terms with the "hurt and anger" many felt as a result of Margaret Thatcher's policies more than two decades ago, a senior clergyman who will greet mourners at her funeral has said.

item.title: Recount demanded in Venezuela vote
item.description: Venezuela's opposition candidate Henrique Capriles Radonski demands a recount following a narrow victory for Hugo Chavez's handpicked successor Nicolas Maduro in the presidential election.

item.title: Capriles brands Maduro illegitimate
item.description: Opposition candidate Henrique Capriles calls Nicolas Maduro an 'illegitimate president.'

item.title: Iraq bombings kill at least 42, wound 257
item.description: A series of car bombings across Iraq on Monday killed at least 19 people and wounded more than 130 others, police said.

item.title: Saudi prince tweets for women driving
item.description: Billionaire Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal has reiterated his support for giving women the right to drive in Saudi Arabia, announcing via Twitter that it would help the economy and reduce the number of foreign workers there.

item.title: Interpol seeks French jail-break fugitive
item.description: Interpol issues an international wanted notice for a notorious French gangster who took hostages and used explosives as part of his brazen escape from prison.

item.title: Cornered thief eats diamond ring
item.description: Caught on cam: Thief swallows ring. Evidence emerges. CNN's Jeanne Moos reports you can bid on this digested diamond.

item.title: In the face of terror, keep calm
item.description: David Rothkopf says in our reaction to the Boston bombings, it's crucial to remember the lessons of 9/11: to respond rationally with purpose and perspective

item.title: Boston's 'greatest day' turns to horror
item.description: Dan Kennedy says until Monday, the Boston Marathon marked a day of patriotism, baseball and Spring's return, a day embedded in the city's civic psyche

item.title: Did Maduro win fair and square?
item.description: Officials in Venezuela say that Nicolas Maduro has won the election, but the opposition is fighting the results.

item.title: No kid should be in solitary confinement
item.description: The 17-year-old drew his suicide note in strips of wet toilet paper on the floor of his jail cell -- a concrete box where he was being held in isolation.

item.title: Pope Francis 'on the right track'
item.description: Thirty days of signs and signals have revealed to the world in Francis I, a pope who seems eager to earn the title pontiff, or bridge-builder. Beginning with his choice of a name, which evokes the beloved image of St. Francis of Assisi, the former cardinal of Buenos Aires, Jorge Mario Bergoglio, put the world on notice that change was afoot by forgoing the fancy red slippers and ermine stole favored by other popes.

item.title: Deadly 7.8 earthquake rocks Iran-Pakistan border
item.description: A 7.8 magnitude quake has hit the Iran-Pakistan border; early reports from the region suggest at least 40 people were killed. Tremors were felt as far afield as Abu Dhabi.

item.title: Quake hits Iran-Pakistan border
item.description: Earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.8 hits Iran-Pakistan border, U.S. Geological Survey reports.

item.title: N. Korea: We won't warn before attack
item.description: North Korea is raising the temperature on its neighbors, warning in a new threat that it would not give any advance notice before attacking South Korea.

item.title: No warning of 'retaliation': N. Korea
item.description: North Korea warns that it would not give any advance notice before attacking South Korea. CNN's Kyung Lah reports.

item.title: North Korea still beating war drums
item.description: CNN's Jim Clancy reports on whether or not North Korea will carry out its threats against the South.

item.title: U.S. Marine 'copter crashes in S. Korea
item.description: A U.S. Marine helicopter participating in annual military exercises in South Korea made a hard landing Tuesday in a province that borders North Korea, the U.S. military said.

item.title: 'No detail too small' in hunt for bomber
item.description: As victims of the Boston Marathon bombing fight for their lives, authorities plead for help to track down those responsible for the blasts which left three people dead.

item.title: Apartment searched in bomber hunt
item.description: Authorities including bomb experts searched an apartment in Revere, Massachusetts, and removed items, after two deadly bombs struck the Boston Marathon. But investigators remained mum about just how the search may be linked to the bombing investigation.

item.title: Eight-year-old boy among bomb victims
item.description: The 8-year-old boy killed in the explosions at the Boston Marathon has been identified as Martin Richard, The Boston Globe reported.

item.title: Pakistani Taliban denies link to blasts
item.description: The Pakistani Taliban denied any involvement in a double bombing at the Boston Marathon that killed at least three people, spokesman Ihsanullah Ihsan said Wednesday.

item.title: Witness tells of 'blood everywhere'
item.description: "I saw blood everywhere," said a Boston.com producer as he described the horror of Monday's tragedy.

item.title: Victims' limbs amputated
item.description: The full horror of Monday's bomb attacks in Boston was reflected in emergency rooms across the city as doctors were forced to carry out amputations and remove ball bearings from some victims.

item.title: Take a closer look at the blast site
item.description: CNN's Tom Foreman takes a closer look at how and where Monday's terror attack in Boston occurred.

item.title: Police review London Marathon security
item.description: The security plan in place for the London Marathon this weekend will be reviewed following the deadly bomb blasts in Boston, London's Metropolitan Police said Tuesday.

item.title: How Korean war might play out
item.description: CNN's Tom Foreman and retired General James Marks map out potential strategies if North Korea attacks South Korea.

item.title: Wearable tech tracks your life
item.description: CNN takes a look at the future of interactive technology.

item.title: The evolution of the cell phone
item.description: CNN's Jim Boulden looks back to the first mobile phone call made 40 years ago.

item.title: Olympic swimmer goes for TV gold
item.description: Anderson Cooper has a preview of Ryan Lochte's upcoming E! reality TV show.

item.title: Are models getting thinner?
item.description: Former fashion editor Kirstie Clements reveals secrets on what models do to stay thin.

item.title: Distraction: Cat walks dog
item.description: Everything is wrong about this. The natural order of things has been disrupted. Run for the hills!

item.title: Madonna and Africa's 'celebrity saviors'
item.description: So finally, Madonna's honeymoon with Malawi has ended with a spat. Malawi's minister of education accused Madonna of "bullying officials" and exaggerating the extent of her charity in the country.

item.title: Turn your phone into a biometric scanner
item.description: A California tech company has launched a tool that turns the iPhone into a powerful biometrics scanning tool.

item.title: Visiting the world's best airport
item.description: CNN's Andrew Stevens explores why Singapore Changi has been voted this year's world's best airport.

item.title: How African doctors can cure 'brain drain'
item.description: One in five African-born doctors are working overseas. But many of them are working to improve healthcare back home.

item.title: 12-ft alligator caught in woman's yard
item.description: A thousand-pound alligator is found on the lawn of a Hilton Head home.

item.title: Natural wonders: A top 10 must-see list
item.description: So very many places to go, yet so little time to pore over the options.

item.title: How does brain respond to music?
item.description: How do our brains respond to music? The quest to dissect exactly what chemical processes occur when we put our headphones on is far from over, but scientists have come across some clues.

item.title: Inside Myanmar with Anthony Bourdain
item.description: A sneak peek of the first episode of Anthony Bourdain Parts Unknown from Myanmar -- Watch the full episode Sunday night at 9pm ET/PT only on CNN.

item.title: Visiting Myanmar: 11 things to know
item.description: Even if you're not planning a trip to Myanmar, take notes and fake it as a Burmese travel expert. Click here for advice on mohawks and more.

item.title: Bourdain on fetal duck egg
item.description: Piers Morgan challenges Anthony Bourdain to a taste test of some bizarre foods. Would you join in the challenge?

item.title: 'Hurt, anger' part of Thatcher legacy
item.description: Dean of St Paul's, Rev. Dr. David Ison talks to CNN's Max Foster about the public reaction to Margaret Thatcher's death.

item.title: What would UK look like without Thatcher
item.description: Many Britons had awoken with a jolt that morning in April 1982 as news of the invasion on their digital radio alarm clocks left them struggling to believe their ears, oblivious even to the breezy new duet by Paul McCartney and Stevie Wonder that followed.

item.title: U.S. drone strikes radicalize Pakistanis
item.description: The Sabaoon School for boys in northern Pakistan is anything but average.

item.title: Acid attack highlights Russian ballet battle
item.description: An acid attack on Bolshoi Theater's artistic director has put the spotlight on a battle for control of the world famous Russian institution.

item.title: Why North Korea 'has already won'
item.description: Even if the crisis ends right now, North Korea will have succeeded in sending a message across the world: that nuclear weapons make you untouchable, writes Frida Ghitis.

item.title: A beauty beyond skin deep
item.description: As a little girl, she never got a valentine at school parties.

item.title: 'Happy' Gilmore defies surfing cliches
item.description: Forget Point Break's party animals, modern surfing is more about professionalism.

item.title: How suicide shaped mom's gun views
item.description: I am a mother of three, and my views on guns have evolved significantly over the course of my lifetime. My husband hunts and believes strongly in his right to bear arms. But when my 25-year-old son, Peter, shot himself in a moment of despair in April 2012, I came full circle to a harsh reality: There are almost twice as many suicides as murders by firearm across America, roughly 19,000 of the 30,000 gun deaths each year. Yet we disproportionately fear and almost exclusively talk of criminals in the national gun debate.

item.title: Will we care about Web privacy in 2033?
item.description: The launch of the Facebook Home app has reignited the privacy debate over whether the social networking site is becoming too integrated in our lives.

item.title: Psy lightens mood with new single
item.description: As tensions on the Korean peninsula go up, Psy parties down and releases a new music video. CNN's Anna Coren reports.

item.title: Attacks 'can happen anywhere'
item.description: If Sept. 11, 2001 was the day everything changed, then April 15, 2013 was the reminder. "It can't happen here" has been replaced by "it can happen anywhere," says LZ Granderson.

item.title: Nations with most malware are...
item.description: Security threats from mobile malware are on the rise and nearly 95% of targets operate on the Android operating system, according to a new report from NQ Mobile.

item.title: Iran's cartoonists score satire hits
item.description: In 2003, former newspaper editor Ali Reza Eshraghi made a mistake that cost him his freedom: he published a cartoon.

item.title: Is criticism of Justin Bieber fair?
item.description: HLN's A.J. Hammer asks whether Justin Bieber deserves all of the criticism for remarks he made about Anne Frank.

item.title: Thatcher funeral sparks controversy
item.description: Former PM Thatcher's funeral could cost more than $15 million with taxpayers picking up the cost. Jim Boulden reports.

item.title: Invasion of giant African land snails
item.description: Florida, already threatened with sinkholes, now has a new terror: rat-sized, tire-puncturing snails.

item.title: Girl's head stuck between walls
item.description: Watch firefighters rescue a 6-year-old girl who accidentally jammed her head between two walls in China.

item.title: Artist earns $$$ with Facebook
item.description: CNN's Anthony Bourdain meets an artist in Los Angeles' Koreatown whose unconventional style has helped him hit it big.

item.title: Bourdain: Humans 'essentially good'
item.description: Before I set out to travel this world, 12 years ago, I used to believe that the human race as a whole was basically a few steps above wolves.

item.title: Google boss: World online by 2020
item.description: Everybody in the world will be on the Internet within seven years. That's what Google Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt said this weekend in public comments that inspired everything from excitement to incredulity.

item.title: North Korea: A tale of two Kims?
item.description: CNN examines the Kim dynasty in North Korea -- and how the leaders' styles align and differ.

item.title: Brazil stadia miss soccer deadline
item.description: Brazil has delivered only four of the six stadiums that will be used in June's Confederations Cup, which is considered a dress rehearsal for next year's World cup, on time.

item.title: Cost of Thatcher's funeral
item.description: Former PM Thatcher's funeral could cost more than $15 million with taxpayers picking up the cost. Jim Boulden reports.

item.title: Cyberbullying and teen suicides
item.description: Online bullying, or trolling, is a disturbing trend that is leading some teens to take their own lives.

item.title: Indian bear dancing fades
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the inhumane tradition of bear dancing in India is fading out. Mallika Kapur reports.

item.title: A beauty that's beyond skin deep
item.description: As a little girl, she never got a valentine at school parties.

item.title: Thatcher history rewritten
item.description: Many Britons had awoken with a jolt that morning in April 1982 as news of the invasion on their digital radio alarm clocks left them struggling to believe their ears, oblivious even to the breezy new duet by Paul McCartney and Stevie Wonder that followed.

item.title: How drone strikes radicalize
item.description: Poor boys in Swat Valley are making ready recruits for the Taliban, which is using the specter of controversial U.S. drone strikes to bring new members into its fold. CNN's Nic Robertson reports.

item.title: Athletes stunned by marathon attack
item.description: Sporting greats including Usain Bolt and LeBron James were quick to tweet messages of shock and sympathy following the deadly blasts in Boston.

item.title: Why I fled North Korea
item.description: Hyeonseo Lee says when she was young she thought her country was normal, even though when she was 7 she saw her first public execution.

item.title: Rarely seen North Korea
item.description: The world is used to seeing glitzy military parades from North Korea but defectors paint a very different picture of the country -- one of people making soup out of grass and risking their lives to escape into China.

item.title: Boston bomber hunt: Home searched
item.description: As victims of the Boston Marathon bombing fight for their lives, authorities plead for help to track down those responsible for the blasts which left three dead and scores wounded.

item.title: Runner, 78: Shock waves hit my body
item.description: Piers Morgan talks with the 78-year-old runner who was knocked to the ground during a bombing at the Boston Marathon.

item.title: Producer captures Boston blast
item.description: Steve Silva, a Boston Globe web producer, was at the scene and captured the Boston Marathon bombing on video.

item.title: Boston attacks
item.description: Two bombs struck near the finish line of the Boston Marathon on Monday, turning a celebration into a bloody scene of destruction.

item.title: FBI investigation
item.description: The FBI is taking the lead in investigating the double bombing that caused death and destruction near the finish line of the Boston Marathon on Monday, authorities said.

item.title: Has N. Korea won?
item.description: World leaders are moving carefully and anxiously, trying to prevent a disaster in the Korean Peninsula. This increasingly unpredictable round of saber-rattling is far from over, but so far the winner is the North Korean regime and the losers are the brutally oppressed North Korean people, joined by much of the rest of the world.

item.title: Bird flu spreads
item.description: Two more people infected with a rare strain of bird flu in China died over the weekend, as the number of human cases of H7N9 climbed to 60, state media reported Sunday.

item.title: Scott wins Masters
item.description: Adam Scott made history by becoming the first Australian to win the U.S. Masters -- avenging compatriot Greg 'The Shark' Norman's 1996 defeat.

item.title: Healthy living in Philippines
item.description: A major housing development in the Philippines tries to combine happy and healthy living. Pauline Chiou reports.

item.title: Reef's beauty captured on film
item.description: Doing for our oceans what Google Street View has done on land, a team of marine scientists is building up an extraordinary picture of the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Our Oceans: Victim or savior?
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China: 60 bird flu cases reported
item.description: China has two new cases of humans infected with bird flu, bringing the total to 51, state media reported Sunday.

item.title: Zao Wou-ki: Painting beyond words
item.description: The Chinese-French painter Zao Wou-ki once told me that painting expresses the thoughts we struggle to put into words. Faced with this challenge, "It's easier to learn English!" he joked, his wit shining through, even though Alzheimer's disease had already begun its slow, relentless onslaught on his mind.

item.title: Can China convince Kim to cool it?
item.description: As North Korea's long-term ally, analysts say China has the greatest potential leverage over the country's young leader. But is it likely to assert itself and would Kim Jong Un even listen?

item.title: Chinese travelers turn to rail
item.description: With less than half an hour to spare, Chen Zhu calmly emerged from the subway station connected to the massive Beijing West Railway Station with a small, wheeled bag.

item.title: 'Daily Show' clip goes viral
item.description: A "Daily Show" clip mocking North Korea has gone viral in China.

item.title: China's GDP expected to grow
item.description: Despite concerns about debt and export growth, China's GDP could see some growth this year.

item.title: China tourism surge: Your views
item.description: We knew even while researching Tuesday's feature on the global impact of Chinese tourism that the story was likely to generate strong reactions among readers.

item.title: Chinese teen to tee off at Masters
item.description: The legendary Jack Nicklaus may have won the most titles, a 21-year-old Tiger Woods may have been the youngest champion and Gary Player may have made the most appearances, but a little-known Chinese golfer will be added to the illustrious list of Masters record-holders on Thursday.
